title: Recurrent gain of function mutation in calcium channel <italic>CACNA1H</italic> causes early-onset hypertension with primary aldosteronism
abstract: Many Mendelian traits are likely unrecognized owing to absence of traditional segregation patterns in families due to causation by de novo mutations, incomplete penetrance, and/or variable expressivity. Genome-level sequencing can overcome these complications. Extreme childhood phenotypes are promising candidates for new Mendelian traits. One example is early onset hypertension, a rare form of a global cause of morbidity and mortality. We performed exome sequencing of 40 unrelated subjects with hypertension due to primary aldosteronism by age 10. Five subjects (12.5%) shared the identical, previously unidentified, heterozygous <italic>CACNA1H</italic><sup>undefined</sup> mutation. Two mutations were demonstrated to be de novo events, and all mutations occurred independently. <italic>CACNA1H</italic> encodes a voltage-gated calcium channel (Ca<sub>V</sub>3.2) expressed in adrenal glomerulosa. CACNA1H<sup>M1549V</sup> showed drastically impaired channel inactivation and activation at more hyperpolarized potentials, producing increased intracellular Ca<sup>2+</sup>, the signal for aldosterone production. This mutation explains disease pathogenesis and provides new insight into mechanisms mediating aldosterone production and hypertension.
